How To Choose the Best Bad Credit Loan Lender

How to choose the best lender for bad credit.

By Timothy Moore

Updated January 31, 2025

Editorial disclosure: Our goal is to give you the tools and confidence you need to improve your finances. Although we receive compensation from our partner lenders, whom we will always identify, all opinions are our own. Credible Operations, Inc. NMLS # 1681276, is referred to here as “Credible.”

    TABLE OF CONTENTS

    View All

    According to FICO, 16.3% of Americans have a credit score below 600. This can make it hard to qualify for a loan. But when unexpected expenses arise, such as car repairs or emergency medical bills, waiting to improve your credit score before applying for a loan may not be practical.

    Luckily, there are ways to get a loan with bad credit. Options include secured loans, loans with a co-borrower, or loans from lenders specializing in bad credit. Alternative borrowing options, such as cash advance apps or buy-now, pay-later (BNPL) programs, may also be available.

    Here's how to choose the best bad credit loan lender for your needs in seven steps.

    Compare personal loans for bad credit borrowers

    Overview

    Upgrade has a suite of features that make it a very attractive lender: competitive interest rates, discounts for direct pay and autopay, as soon as same-day funding, up to seven-year repayment terms, and nationwide availability. Plus, loans are available to fair-credit borrowers and borrowers with low annual incomes. Upgrade even offers secured personal loans, which is not common among lenders.

     

    However, Upgrade does charge an origination fee of 1.85% to 9.99%.

    pros

    • Fair-credit eligible
    • Secured loan options
    • Joint applications accepted
    • Fast funding
    • Small loans available
    • Low income requirement

    cons

    • High APRs for fair credit
    • Origination fees
    • Risk of collateral loss

    Overview

    Avant personal loans are a good choice for borrowers with bad credit looking for small- to moderate-sized personal loans. Loans are available up to $35,000 and you could get the money as soon as the next business day after approval. Plus, Avant is more likely than some lenders to approve the applications of borrowers who've prequalified with Avant. However, the lender charges an origination fee up to 9.99%, and its top-range interest rates are among the highest of the lenders we reviewed.

    pros

    • Borrowers with bad credit considered
    • Funds as soon as the next business day
    • 2-year loan terms available

    cons

    • Origination fee

    Overview

    Reprise may be an excellent option if you need a loan with bad credit. Not only does it offer bad credit loans, but the lender delivered the lowest rates, on average, to borrowers with bad credit compared to other Credible partners offering loans for bad credit. (Average interest rates are based on Credible personal loans data across credit score tiers over the last 12 months.) The lender also offers secured loans as well as some cosigned loans to help you qualify. 

     

    Reprise loans are a great options for emergencies as loan funds can be available the next business day once you’re approved. Plus, the company has a 4.7 Trustpilot rating and a 4.16 customer rating on BBB (the Better Business Bureau) — indicating satisfied customers.

     

    But Reprise is not for everyone. Available loan amounts are capped at a relatively low $25,000, Reprise may charge an origination fee, and there are no discounts for autopay or direct pay to creditors when using the loan to consolidate debt.  

    pros

    • Low rates for bad credit
    • Next-day funding available
    • Secured loans
    • Extended customer service hours

    cons

    • Not best for self-employed
    • Low loan maximum
    • Origination fee
    • Not available in all states

    Loan amount

    $2,500 to $25,000 (Minimum $5,000 for OH, Minimum $3,500 for GA)

    Repayment terms

    3 to 5 years

    Fees

    $15 late fee except where the state has a different limit (ie. NM), return payment fees - $20 except where state has a different limit (ie – NM), and no prepayment penalty

    Discounts

    None

    Eligibility

    Unavailable in CO, CT, HI, IA, ME, MD, MA, NV, NJ, NY, PA, SD, VT, WA, and WV

    Min. income

    $30,000

    Customer service

    Phone

    Soft credit check

    Does not disclose

    Time to get funds

    1-7 business days depending on loan security type

    Loan uses

    Credit card refinancing, debt consolidation, emergencies, major purchases, medical and dental expenses, moving expenses, special occasions, unexpected expenses, vacation and travel

    $1,500 to $20,000

    N/A

    Apply

    on Credible’s website

    View Details

    Overview

    OneMain Financial has multiple options for bad-credit personal loans. There is no minimum credit score required (if you apply directly with OneMain), which means you could get a loan with bad credit (FICO below 580). Plus, cosigners are allowed — a cosigner is someone (ideally, with good credit) who promises to repay the loan if you can't, which can make it easier to qualify or lower your rate. And, secured personal loans are available. You secure a loan with collateral, which may also help you qualify or lower your rate.

     

    Rates are higher than competitors and OneMain charges origination fees as either a flat fee up to $500, or a percentage from 1% to 10% (depending on your state of residence). Note that even if you prequalify for a personal loan with OneMain, getting approved isn't a given. 

    pros

    • Flexible eligibility requirements
    • Offers secured options
    • Competitive bad-credit loans
    • Physical presence

    cons

    • Availability
    • Origination fees
    • High starting APR
    • Low maximum loan amount

    Loan amount

    $1,500 to $20,000

    Fees

    Origination fee, unsuccessful payment fee, late fee

    Discounts

    None

    Eligibility

    Must have photo I.D. issued by U.S. federal, state or local government

    Min. income

    Does not disclose

    Customer service

    Phone, email

    Soft credit check

    Yes

    Time to get funds

    As soon as 1 to 2 days after acceptance

    Loan use

    All except business, and education

    Overview

    OneMain Financial has multiple options for bad-credit personal loans. There is no minimum credit score required (if you apply directly with OneMain), which means you could get a loan with bad credit (FICO below 580). Plus, cosigners are allowed — a cosigner is someone (ideally, with good credit) who promises to repay the loan if you can't, which can make it easier to qualify or lower your rate. And, secured personal loans are available. You secure a loan with collateral, which may also help you qualify or lower your rate.

     

    Rates are higher than competitors and OneMain charges origination fees as either a flat fee up to $500, or a percentage from 1% to 10% (depending on your state of residence). Note that even if you prequalify for a personal loan with OneMain, getting approved isn't a given.

    1. Confirm what loan term works best for you

    Start by determining how much money you need and how long you'll need to repay it. Short-term borrowing options, such as cash advance apps and payday loans, typically require repayment by your next paycheck. While practical for small amounts, these options may not be ideal if you need a larger loan or more time to repay.

    For instance, personal loan term lengths generally range from 1 to 7 years, though this varies by lender. Consider your repayment ability and the time required to pay off the loan to narrow your search.

    2. Review loan types and availability

    Once you've determined the repayment term you need, review the types of bad credit loans available:

    Short-term loans for bad credit

    • Cash advance apps: These allow you to access a portion of your paycheck early. Fees may apply, and repeated use can lead to a cycle of borrowing, as repayment comes directly from your next paycheck.
    • BNPL programs: Buy now, pay later apps split the cost of a purchase into smaller payments. Each program works differently, but a common structure is to make one payment at purchase and then three more within a given time period. Short-term repayments might be interest- and fee-free, but longer repayment periods may come with interest or fees.
    • Payday loans: High-cost loans requiring repayment by your next paycheck. These should be a last resort due to predatory practices and APRs reaching 400%, according to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

    Expert insight

    “Short-term borrowing options can lead to a cycle of debt if not managed carefully,” says Xavier Epps, CEO of XNE Financial Advising. “The risks include late fees, credit damage, and overextension of financial resources.”

    That said, such borrowing may be unavoidable. “It's easy to sit back and say never use a cash advance app, but if you're trying to feed your family or keep the furnace on in the winter, that's a lot different,” says R.J. Weiss, Certified Financial Planner and founder of The Ways to Wealth. “Yes, you want to avoid these forms of debt whenever possible, but as a last resort, they can help in urgent situations. The key is to borrow only what you absolutely need and have a plan to pay it back quickly.”

    Long-term loans for bad credit

    • Personal loans: These installment loans typically have terms of 1 to 7 years and can be used for various purposes, such as debt consolidation or home renovations. Interest rates often max out at 36%.
    • Payday alternative loans (PALs): Offered by credit unions, payday alternative loans have consumer-friendly terms and are easier to qualify for compared to payday loans. PALs are a credit union-exclusive loan designed with far more consumer protections than a payday loan. They're governed by the National Credit Union Administration (NCUA).
    • Credit card cash advances: These let you withdraw cash from your credit card's available credit. Be cautious of high APRs (usually 30%) and transaction fees.

    No-credit-check options

    Some lenders and products may not require a credit check, but be prepared for higher fees, interest rates, and limited borrowing amounts.

    Learn More: Types of Bad-Credit Loans and Common Uses

    3. Review eligibility requirements

    You might wonder how much of a personal loan you can get with your credit score — or if you can qualify at all? But a credit score only paints part of the picture. In addition to minimum credit score thresholds, lenders may have several other eligibility requirements for personal loans, including:

    • Debt-to-income ratio: This is a measure of your monthly debt obligations compared to your monthly income. Lenders generally want to see a debt-to-income (DTI) ratio of 36% or less, but some may accept slightly higher DTIs. If you're getting a personal loan to consolidate debt, lenders may be more lax about this.
    • Employment and income: Lenders want to know that you're able to make monthly payments. Proof of employment or a source of monthly income is thus a common requirement for a personal loan.
    • Collateral or co-borrower: If you have bad credit, you may also need to get a secured loan by offering collateral; your house or car is common collateral for a personal loan. Alternatively, you may need a co-borrower with better credit to sign the loan with you.

    In addition, lenders typically have requirements regarding age and citizenship for personal loans.

    Good to know

    Some loan products, such as cash advance apps and BNPL apps, may not be available in every state. Payday alternative loans are only available to members of the credit union offering them.

    Learn More: What Are the Requirements for a Personal Loan?

    4. Prequalify with several lenders

    While the pool of lenders offering bad credit personal loans is small, there are still plenty of lenders to consider.

    Use an online loan marketplace to compare multiple lenders in one place. You can usually get prequalified for a loan without an impact on your credit score. While prequalification does not guarantee approval, it'll give you a good idea of whether you're likely to be approved — and at what rate and with what fees. Once you apply for a loan, most lenders will conduct a hard credit pull, which could temporarily ding your credit.

    Once you're prequalified with a few lenders, compare personal loan rates and fees to find the best offer.

    But remember, online lenders aren't your only option. You may have good luck with a local brick-and-mortar bank or credit union. Credit unions can be especially helpful for members, even if you don't ultimately get your loan through yours.

    Pro tip

    “Check with your local credit union, especially if you’re a member,” advises Weiss. “Sit down with someone and explain your situation. You’ll get some valuable feedback.”

    5. Assess lender reputation through customer reviews

    There's more to compare than simply rates and fees, however. If you're taking out a personal loan that you'll repay for years, you'll want to find a reputable lender with happy customers.

    Use review sites, such as Better Business Bureau and Trustpilot, to learn more about each lender you're considering. Take note of what other customers are saying about:

    • Hidden fees
    • App usability
    • Customer service

    Looking at app reviews in the Apple App Store and Google Play can also provide insight into each lender.

    6. Consider other perks

    When you're comparing loans, rate, fees, and customer reviews are all important, but there's more to a personal loan to consider:

    • Funding speed: Some personal loans offer same- or next-day funding. If you need money ASAP, prioritize loans with lightning-fast funding.
    • Direct payment: Using a personal loan to consolidate your debts and make a real effort at becoming debt-free? Some lenders will pay your creditors directly. Some, like Universal Credit and Upgrade, may even discount your rate for doing so.
    • Automatic payments: Most online lenders offer an autopay feature. If you've had trouble remembering to pay your credit card bills in the past, this will be a useful feature to ensure you don't fall behind on payments.

    Other loan products for borrowers with bad credit may have additional perks. Credit-builder loans, for instance, may offer free credit score monitoring.

    7. Review fine print

    The last thing to review when choosing a bad-credit loan lender is the fine print. Scour the terms and conditions to get a feel for things like:

    • Origination fees: These increase the loan's APR and reduce the amount you receive.
    • Late fees: Fees can vary widely between lenders.
    • Pre-payment penalties: These are uncommon among personal loan lenders. If a loan you're considering charges one, you may want to look elsewhere.
    • Rate contingencies: Some lenders may offer a certain APR only if you sign up for autopay. If you're not comfortable using autopay (because of the risk of overdrafting your checking account), adjust your expectations for the rate or find a lender with a better offer.

    How to apply for a bad credit personal loan

    Applying for a personal loan with bad credit is much like the process of applying for a personal loan with good credit. Your pool of options will just be smaller — and you'll likely face higher rates and fees.

    1. Get a handle on your finances: Check your credit score, calculate your debt-to-income ratio, and figure out just how much you need to borrow. Knowing these parameters will help you filter your search to lenders that are likely to approve your application.
    2. Compare lenders: Using the steps we outlined above, compare multiple lenders to see which advertise the lowest rates and fees but also have a solid reputation with customers.
    3. Prequalify: Once you've narrowed down your list, get prequalified with the remaining lenders. This should be a soft credit check with no impact to your credit score — and will help you determine which lender will give you the lowest rate and fees.
    4. Fill out the application: Online lenders make the application process easy, but you'll still need to find paperwork such as recent pay stubs or tax returns to get approved. You'll also need to provide bank information so the lender can fund your account. Your credit score may drop a few points if the lender conducts a hard credit check at this stage.

    Pro tip

    If your credit report is frozen, you’ll need to temporarily thaw it before you apply for a personal loan. Official applications will trigger a credit check.

    Learn More: How To Apply for a Personal Loan

    FAQ

    Can I get a personal loan with a 500 credit score?

    Open

    While most lenders require a credit score in the 600s or above, some may approve a loan for a borrower with fair credit (580 or above). Getting approved for a personal loan with a 500 credit score is more challenging — and expensive.

     

    Some lenders specialize in bad credit personal loans, but the origination fees and interest rates will likely be significantly higher, and loan amounts and terms are often stricter. You may also be able to get a secured personal loan (requiring collateral) or a loan with a co-borrower who has a stronger credit score.

    Read more: How and Where To Get a 500 Credit Score Loan

    How long does it take to get a bad credit personal loan?

    Open

    The time it takes to get a personal loan with bad credit depends on the lender. Some lenders approve applications and can send money to your bank account all in one day. But other lenders may take a few business days. Online lenders, which are more likely to offer bad credit personal loans, are often faster than traditional banks and credit unions.

    Read more: How Long Does It Take To Get a Personal Loan?

    What are some alternatives to a bad credit personal loan?

    Open

    If you have bad credit but need to pay bills now, a personal loan isn't your only option. Consider alternatives such as:

    • Cash advance apps
    • BNPL programs
    • Payday alternative loans

    Avoid payday loans, which can have APRs over 400%.

    Read more: Best Personal Loan Alternatives

    How can I improve my credit score fast?

    Open

    These are some of the fastest ways to improve your credit score:

    • Paying off large chunks of debt to reduce your overall credit utilization
    • Reviewing your credit report and contesting any errors to have them removed
    • Become an authorized user on a loved one's credit card, assuming they manage it responsibly

    Read more: How To Build Your Credit: A Step-by-Step Guide
